background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate an example of a challenge faced when collecting multiscale observations in eco-hydrological research?
Example.Answer: A challenge in collecting multiscale observations is the poor availability of such data, which hinders progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. HiWATER addresses this by employing instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales.

Definition.Question: What is the concept of 'multiscale observations' in the context of eco-hydrological processes?
Definition.Answer: Multiscale observations refer to collecting data at various hierarchical levels to capture complex eco-hydrological processes. This approach involves using different observational tools and techniques to gather data across different scales, as implemented in the HiWATER experiment, which used hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.

Definition.Question: How is 'data quality control' defined in the process of generating observational datasets?
Definition.Answer: Data quality control in the process of generating observational datasets involves ensuring the accuracy and reliability of data through careful sensor calibration, consistent data collection, thorough data processing, and systematic datasets generation. This process is crucial to maintaining the integrity of the data, as emphasized in the HiWATER and other related eco-hydrological studies.

Definition.Question: What does 'oasis–desert interaction' mean in the context of hydrometeorological observations?
Definition.Answer: Oasis–desert interaction refers to the dynamic exchanges and processes between oasis ecosystems and surrounding desert areas. In hydrometeorological observations, this concept involves studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges to understand the ecological balance and support sustainable development in arid and semi-arid regions.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in the HiWATER experiment compare to those used for the 黑河生态水文遥感试验 in terms of capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes?
Comparison.Answer: The HiWATER experiment uses hierarchically nested scales with a combination of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes. In contrast, the 黑河生态水文遥感试验 primarily utilizes pressure-type water level meters and ultrasonic distance meters for river water level observations with a focus on a specific observation point in the Heihe River Basin.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when interpreting multiscale eco-hydrological data from a heterogeneous oasis-desert system, and how can these be addressed through data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Interpreting multiscale eco-hydrological data in a heterogeneous oasis-desert system presents challenges, such as capturing the complex interactions between different landscape elements and the variability of environmental processes across scales. These challenges can be addressed by employing a hierarchically nested instrumentation approach, which includes a combination of eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing tools. This approach allows for capturing data at various scales, thus providing a more comprehensive understanding of ecological processes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in obtaining multiscale observations for eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous surfaces?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Progress in the field of eco-hydrological processes is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations, which is a significant challenge in obtaining comprehensive data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the ecological environment degradation in inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The ecological environment degradation in inland river basins is attributed to the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it critical to balance oasis and desert systems in arid and semiarid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial to achieve sustainable oasis development, support ecological security, and ensure the socioeconomic development of oases.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using multiscale and multidisciplinary data collection methods on the accuracy and comprehensiveness of eco-hydrological studies in oasis-desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of multiscale and multidisciplinary data collection methods can enhance the accuracy and comprehensiveness of eco-hydrological studies in oasis-desert systems by capturing multi-scale processes and interactions. This approach allows for detailed observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which are crucial for understanding oasis-desert interactions and supporting sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of employing hierarchically nested scales in eco-hydrological data collection within heterogeneous landscapes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data that can help in understanding and upscaling eco-hydrological processes, which is essential for addressing the challenge posed by the poor availability of multiscale observations in heterogeneous surfaces.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to gather long-term hydrometeorological observations in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observations are crucial for understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas, which is significant for recognizing oasis-desert interactions, maintaining ecological stability, and supporting sustainable socio-economic development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are hierarchically nested scales utilized to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in an oasis-desert system?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales, including the use of a sparse network with one superstation within the oasis and other installations such as EC towers and automatic meteorological stations in surrounding landscapes like sandy desert and wetland. Intensive observations were also implemented at the irrigation district scale.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps for collecting and processing hydrometeorological data in inland river basins within arid and semiarid areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Hydrometeorological data are observed from automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period and include parameters like radiation, soil heat flux, and soil moisture profiles. The data processing and quality control procedure is divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumentation and methods are used to gather multiscale observations in eco-hydrological experiments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The HiWATER experiment employs a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. Additionally, eco-hydrological sensor networks for soil moisture and leaf area index, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer, as well as synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes are used.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the collection of multiscale and multidisciplinary eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of multiscale and multidisciplinary eco-hydrological data is enabled by the use of hierarchically nested scales of instrumentation, such as flux observation matrices consisting of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and an eco-hydrological sensor network for soil moisture and leaf area index.

Enablement.Question: How do intensive observation periods (IOPs) contribute to the understanding of oasis-desert interactions?
Enablement.Answer: Intensive observation periods (IOPs) contribute to understanding oasis-desert interactions by employing a sparse network of instruments at different landscape scales, including superstations, eddy covariance towers, and automatic meteorological stations, to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes and interactions.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do airborne remote sensing techniques enhance data collection for eco-hydrological research in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Airborne remote sensing techniques enhance data collection by providing hyper-resolution observations using LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers, which complement ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in acquiring multiscale eco-hydrological observations in oasis-desert areas?
Expectation.Answer: Progress in the field of eco-hydrological processes is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. This is due to the complex nature of the heterogeneous surfaces in the oasis-desert areas and the need for instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to capture these processes effectively.

Expectation.Question: Why is it critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems for sustainable development?
Expectation.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial to achieving the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, as well as supporting the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. This balance is necessary to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems, which is significant for ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Expectation.Question: What are some of the anticipated challenges in long-term observations in inland river basins of arid and semiarid areas?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face challenges such as ecological environment degradation, drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges complicate the collection of long-term observational data necessary for understanding and managing these regions.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are multiscale observation networks in capturing the complexity of eco-hydrological processes in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Multiscale observation networks, such as those used in the HiWATER experiment, are crucial for addressing the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations in eco-hydrological processes. By employing instruments at hierarchically nested scales, these networks can capture a wide range of eco-hydrological processes and interactions across different landscapes, enhancing the understanding of oasis-desert systems.

Judgmental.Question: What are the primary challenges in maintaining long-term dataset accuracy and quality control in hydrometeorological observations?
Judgmental.Answer: Maintaining long-term dataset accuracy and quality control in hydrometeorological observations involves challenges such as sensor calibration, data processing, and ensuring consistent data collection and archiving. The HiWATER observation system highlights the importance of careful quality control throughout these processes to ensure reliable data for eco-hydrological research.

Assertion.Answer: In the HiWATER experiment, instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales is used to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes by arranging instruments like eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations at different scales. This setup allows for the collection of detailed observations across various landscapes, such as sandy desert and wetland, providing comprehensive data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the methods used to ensure quality control of observational data in eco-hydrological research.
Assertion.Answer: Quality control of observational data in this field involves careful sensor calibration, systematic data collection, thorough data processing, and the generation of datasets. For instance, in the studies mentioned, data were quality-controlled to ensure accurate representation of eco-hydrological processes and were made available through platforms like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe a comprehensive approach for collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data in an oasis-desert area, considering both ground-based and airborne techniques.
Request/Directive.Answer: A comprehensive approach for collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data in an oasis-desert area involves the use of a flux observation matrix that includes eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. Additionally, an eco-hydrological sensor network for soil moisture and leaf area index should be established. Hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer can be integrated. Synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes are also crucial. The data collection should be carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in maintaining long-term observations for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges in maintaining long-term observations for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems include ecological environment degradation such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These issues are particularly prevalent in inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas, such as the Tarim River basin, the Aral Sea basin, and the Lake Urmia basin. Ensuring consistent and accurate data collection over long periods amidst these challenges requires robust data processing and quality control procedures.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that can be used to study the hydrometeorological characteristics of oasis-desert systems and their ecological interactions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets that can be used to study the hydrometeorological characteristics of oasis-desert systems and their ecological interactions include observations of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. These datasets often include auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, which are collected using an eddy covariance system, scintillometer, and automatic weather stations. Data from these sources typically cover gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, soil moisture profiles, and groundwater table data. The data are available from resources such as the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.
